column1: Port & TCP or UDP> FTP: Data Connection
column3: Used for transferring files after control connection is established.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> FTP: Control Connection
column3: Manages the FTP session and authentication.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> SSH
column3: Secure remote login and command execution.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> Telnet
column3: Unsecure text-based remote login (not recommended).

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> SMTP
column3: Used to send email between mail servers.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> SMTP Secure
column3: Secure version of SMTP using STARTTLS.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> DNS
column3: Resolves hostnames to IP addresses (TCP for zone transfers; UDP for queries).

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> DHCP: Server Port>Provisions IP from here
column3: Server side of DHCP handshake.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> DHCP: Client Port>Requests IP from here
column3: Client side of DHCP handshake.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> HTTPS
column3: Secure web traffic using SSL/TLS.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> POP
column3: Downloads email to a single device and deletes it from server.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> POP Secure
column3: Secure version of POP using SSL/TLS.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> NetBIOS over TCP/IP
column3: Name datagram and session services for legacy systems.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> IMAP
column3: Email access protocol that syncs across devices.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> IMAP Secure
column3: Secure version of IMAP.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> SNMP Query status from network devices
column3: Used by SNMP manager to poll devices.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> SNMP Trap
column3: Used by devices to send alerts/events to SNMP manager.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> LDAP
column3: Lightweight directory access (like AD) over TCP. Rarely UDP can be used

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> Syslog
column3: Protocol and supporting software that facilitates log collection

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> LDAPS
column3: Lightweight directory access (like AD) over TCP using SSL/TLS.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> SMB
column3: Windows file and printer sharing over TCP.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> RDP
column3: Remote desktop protocol to connect to Windows systems.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> mDNS
column3: Used for local hostname resolution without DNS server.

column1: Port & TCP or UDP> WS-Discovery
column3: Helps discover services on local network (mostly Windows). means Web Services Dynamic Discovery.

column1: 2.4 GHz Channel 1-13 Frequencies
column3: Each channel steps 5 MHz; avoid overlap for better Wi-Fi; channel 14 is 2.484 (+12 jump)

column1: 5 GHz Channel U-NII-1 20 Mhz channels low-high
column3: Not in DFS range

column1: 5 GHz Channel U-NII-2 20 Mhz channels low-high
column3: Inside DFS range

column1: 5 GHz Channel U-NII-2 (Extended) 20 Mhz channels low-high
column3: Inside DFS range

column1: 5 GHz Channel U-NII-3 20 Mhz channels low-high
column3: Not in DFS range

column1: Adobe's PDL
column3: Used mostly for high-quality prints and graphics.

column1: HP's PDL (Acronym)
column3: Printer Control Language; efficient but less precise than PS.

column1: Microsoft's PDL (Acronym)
column3: XML-based print language used in Windows. XML Paper Specification

column1: IDC on Patch Panel (Meaning)
column3: Wire pierces insulation to connect without stripping.

column1: 3D Print FFF (Meaning)
column3: Consumer-friendly 3D print method (same as FDM).

column1: 3D Print FDM (Meaning)
column3: Another name for FFF; filament melted and layered.

column1: MDI (Meaning) *cabling*
column3: Used in networking—MDI vs MDI-X (crossover).

column1: What is the maximum number of primary partitions on an MBR disk?
column3: Master Boot Record only supports 4 primary or 3 + 1 extended partition.

column1: What is the maximum number of partitions on a GPT disk?
column3: GUID Partition Table supports up to 128 partitions with no extended/logical distinction (GUID = Globally Unique Identifier)

column1: USB 2.0 is a high speed standard that specifies a data rate of:
column3: shared between all devices attached to the same controller.

column1: USB 1.1 maximum speed
column3: Rarely asked/but may be mentioned as "Full Speed"

column1: TCP/IP protocol used to query and update resources in an X.500 directory.
column3: primarily uses TCP (port 389) for unencrypted communication and TCP (port 636) for encrypted communication (LDAPS)

column1: AAA First A?
column3: Verifies identity—"Are you who you say you are?"

column1: AAA Second A?
column3: Grants access—"What are you allowed to do?"

column1: AAA Third A?
column3: Tracks activity—"What did you do and when?"

column1: Device Requesting Access in an AAA Setup
column3: The device (like a user computer or phone) that is trying to gain access to the network

column1: Server that uses RADIUS or TACACS+
column3: Performs authentication/authorization/and accounting tasks using protocols like RADIUS or TACACS+

column1: RADIUS (R and A Mean?)
column3: RADIUS: Used for verifying the identity of clients before granting access to a network

column1: RADIUS (DIUS Means?)
column3: RADIUS: Originally designed for dial-up but now used for centralized AAA over IP networks

column1: NAS Meaning related to AAA
column3: Acts as the gateway device between the user and the AAA server / Firewalls/Switches/VPN Gateways

column1: NAP Meaning related to AAA
column3: Evaluates device health/compliance before allowing full access / Often part of network access control (NAC) systems (eg. ISP NAC or Managed Switch Port)

column1: IEEE 802.3af PoE Watts <100m/>328ft
column3: PoE Type 1/Delivers 15.4 W but device receives less over distance (Short: 14+/ Long ~13)

column1: IEEE meaning
column2: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
column3: does the 802.whatever standards.

column1: IEEE 802.3af PoE #mA@#V
column3: Provides ~13W usable power to PD at 100m/Phones; access points; cameras

column1: IEEE 802.3at standard PoE Watts/mA
column3: PoE Type 2 (PoE+)/Delivers up to 25 W/Used for higher-power WAPs and cameras/Cameras with heaters; better APs

column1: IEEE 802.3bt standard PoE Watts Type3/Type4
column3: PoE++ Type 3 and 4/Device receives ~51 W or ~73 W/Source may deliver 60–100 W/Lighting; PTZ cams; multi-radio APs

column1: Adds PoE to a non PoE connection
column3: One port on the injector is connected to the switch port. The other port is connected to the device. The overall cable length cannot exceed 100m.

column1: WPA2 Meaning (WPA2 or WPA3)
column3: A security standard for wireless networks - better user authentication than WEP

column1: WEP Meaning
column3: the oldest and most common Wi-Fi security protocol - vulnerable to security breaches

column1: Blank Pages or White Stripes (Laser Print Stage) Toner/driver is fine/toner seal removed
column3: Transfer Roller is dirty or damaged

column1: WPA2-Enterprise requires?
column3: Used in enterprise environments to authenticate users individually using 802.1X

column1: M.2 adapter sizes(mm) no spaces
column3: (B-Key = 6 Pin & SATA or x2)/(M-Key = 5 Pin & x4)/(B+M-Key = SATA or x2)

column1: FDI Meaning (PCH Feature)
column3: Transmits display output data from the integrated GPU (iGPU) inside the CPU to the PCH

column1: PCH Meaning
column3: Replaced Southbridge and took over some Northbridge roles like clocking while CPU now handles RAM and PCIe

column1: DMI Meaning (Motherboards)
column3: Connects the processor and the Platform Control Hub (PCH)

column1: RSSI Meaning
column3: measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm). Closer to 0 is better (-30 dBm is great)

column1: SCADA Meaning (Embedded Systems)
column3: typically run as software on ordinary computers; gathering data from and managing plant devices and equipment with embedded PLCs; referred to as "field devices."

column1: Three items that define a problem
column3: Once the symptoms are defined; narrow down the cause. Identifying the cause of the problem is an important problem-solving step.

column1: PLC Meaning (Embedded Systems)
column3: Linked by a cabled network to actuators that operate valves/motors/circuit breakers/other mechanical components/sensors - Output and configuration done at HMI's.

column1: HDD slow read/write cause?
column3: Physical/logical drive issues cause performance drop; NOT disk thrashing (RAM issue)

column1: BCD store meaning on an MBR Disk
column3: Where Windows boot options are stored. It includes boot configuration parameters for how to launch Windows. GRUB or LILO is Linux equivalent.

column1: GPT meaning in disk partitioning/boot scheme
column3: boot information is not restricted to a single sector but still serves the same basic purpose of identifying partitions and OS boot loaders.

column1: SMART meaning
column3: Fixed disk self-diagnostic program. SMART can alert the operating system if a failure is detected.

column1: VDI meaning
column3: Using VM's as a means of Provisioning corporate desktops; often accessed via thin clients. Server-side virtualization where desktop environments are hosted on a centralized server

column1: ONT meaning
column3: installed at the customer’s premises converts the optical signal to an electrical one. Connected to the customer’s router using an RJ45 copper wire patch cord.

column1: OLT meaning
column3: Located in a street cabinet. From the OLT- splitters direct each subscriber’s traffic over a short length of fiber to an optical network terminal (ONT) installed at the customer’s premises.

column1: PoP meaning
column3: A connection to an internet service provider's (ISP’s) network uses its nearest point of presence (PoP) such as a local telephone exchange.

column1: PON meaning
column3: In a PON- FTTP: a single fiber cable is run from the point of presence to a street cabinet; a splitter directs traffic over a shorter length fiber to ONT on premises.

column1: Small core fiber that carries long wavelength
column3: SMF: supports data rates up to 10 Gbps and cable runs of many kilometers. 8-10 micron core/1310 or 1550 nm wavelength.

column1: Large core fiber that carries shorter wavelengths
column3: MMF: slower signal speeds and shorter distances - better for LANs than WANs. 50 or 62.5 micron core/850 or 1300 nm wavelength. Cheaper.

column1: VCSEL
column3: Low-cost laser used in Multi-mode fiber; faster than LED; good for short-range fiber like 10GBASE-SR

column1: Fiber: bayonet-style connector that uses a push-and-twist locking mechanism
column3: ST: bayonet-style; push-and-twist; used mostly on older multi-mode networks.

column1: Fiber: simple push/pull connector
column3: SC: simple push/pull insertion. Simplex and Duplex versions (duplex = 2 connectors clipped together). Single or Multi-Mode.

column1: Fiber: small/tabbed push/pull connector
column3: LC: small form factor; Tabbed push/pull design. Small size allows higher port density than SC.

column1: When should a tech perform a backup during troubleshooting?
column3: Backups are part of identifying the problem to avoid data loss before performing repairs

column1: What does UEFI stand for?
column3: UEFI provides support for 64-bit CPU operation at boot; a full GUI and mouse operation at boot; networking functionality at boot; and better boot security.

column1: First step if you are working inside the case
column3: Perform backups if possible prior to working inside the case as well.

column1: Applies a continuous audio signal on the cable
column3: A Toner Probe is used to detect the signal and follow the cable or identify from a bundle.

column1: Finish connecting cable to an IDC
column3: Cable Stripper and Snips needed to expose inner wires and snip Star Filler and Rip Cord.

column1: Finish connecting an RJ45 jack to cable
column3: Cable Stripper and Snips needed to expose inner wires and snip Star Filler and Rip Cord

column1: TIA meaning
column3: TIA develops cabling and communications standards such as TIA/EIA-568 for structured cabling

column1: Multiple execution units and registers in a CPU
column3: (CMP): A multi-core CPU has multiple processors (cores) in one chip; allowing simultaneous execution of tasks

column1: The use of two or more physical CPUs in a multi-socket motherboard
column3: An SMP-aware OS can then make efficient use of CPUs on a multi-socket motherboard.

column1: EM64T Meaning
column3: Intels 64-bit processor architechture; also just called Intel64 (x86-64 generally / AMD64 from AMD)

column1: Two types of Ethernet Cable with different physical properties ?/?
column3: Each of the 8 wires is solid copper in solid-core cables; made of tiny strands in stranded cables.

column1: ALU Meaning?
column3: A combinational digital circuit that performs arithmetic and bitwise operations on integer binary numbers.

column1: FPU Meaning?
column3: Provides a faster way for the CPU to handle calculations with non-integer numbers.

column1: 4 steps in CPU execution process
column3: Fetch gets instruction from memory; decode interprets it; execute performs it; writeback stores result in register or memory

column1: RISC Meaning?
column3: A typical Advanced RISC Machines (ARM) design implements a system-on-chip (SoC). SoC means that all the controllers—video; sound; networking; and storage—are part of the CPU.

column1: Allows multiple threads to run through the CPU at the same time
column3: (SMT): referred to as HyperThreading by Intel. One core runs multiple threads by using idle units (ALU/FPU/etc..) that the other thread isn't using

column1: Intel/AMD CPU level virtualization optimization designations (short form)
column3: Required for Type 1 & 2 hypervisors to run VMs efficiently (Virtualization Technology / AMD Virtualization)

column1: Why is SLAT useful?
column3: Handles second-level memory (address) translation in hardware to improve performance

column1: When removing a CPU with a heat sink and fan assembly how to remove heat sink
column3: to remove the heat sink to avoid it sticking to the CPU.

column1: Common AMD desktop CPU socket/type
column3: Pin Grid Array; The platform for select AMD Ryzen(gen 1-5); Athlon; and 7th Gen A-Series processors

column1: What is the EDB?
column3: connects the processor to adapters; the keyboard; the mouse; the hard drive; and other devices.

column1: What does Ryzen 7 mean?
column3: AMD CPU tier similar to Intel i7

column1: What does the 5 in Ryzen 5800X mean?
column3: Higher generations = newer/better

column1: What does 800 mean in Ryzen 5800X?
column3: Higher number = more powerful model

column1: What does the X mean in Ryzen 5800X?
column3: Indicates unlocked/high-performance model

column1: Intel LGA 1150 Socket generations (Core CPUs)
column3: Supports Haswell and Broadwell CPUs released around 2013–2015; replaced by LGA 1151

column1: Intel LGA 1151 Socket generations (Core CPUs)
column3: Common desktop CPUs like i5-8400 use this socket; DDR4 supported

column1: Intel LGA 1200 Socket generations (Core CPUs)
column3: Replaced 1151 with slight design changes; still uses DDR4

column1: Intel LGA 1700 Socket generations (Core CPUs)
column3: Supports DDR5 or DDR4 depending on motherboard; longer socket

column1: Sockets used by Intel Xeon Processors ?/?/?
column3: LGA Workstation/server CPUs; not typically seen on desktops

column1: AMD Ryzen 1000–5000 Series Socket
column3: Uses PGA Layout; Most Ryzen CPUs up to 2022 use this socket

column1: AMD Ryzen 7000 and newer Socket
column3: Uses LGA layout and supports DDR5 memory

column1: AMD EPYC Socket
column3: Used in servers and workstations; large LGA socket for multi-core CPUs

column1: 25 pin or more common 9 pin DB-9
column3: legacy serial ports - also known as a COM port - not to be confused with 15 pin VGA ports

column1: SCSI Meaning/Max Data Rate (MBps)
column3: high density (HD) 68-pin or single connector attachment (SCA) 80-pin most common (A legacy parallel bus)

column1: UART Meaning
column3: Converts data between parallel and serial form; used in low-speed communication like debugging or with Bluetooth/USB and embedded systems

column1: What can use UART on modern mobile devices?
column3: Bluetooth modules and USB controllers often use UART for low-level serial communication

column1: HMI Meaning
column3: Touchscreen or control panel that allows a person to interact with a machine or industrial system

column1: ICS Meaning
column3: General term for systems used to control industrial processes; often includes PLCs and SCADA

column1: UTM Meaning
column3: All-in-one network security appliance with features like firewall; content filtering; and malware scanning

column1: A device programmed with scripts that can identify known malicious traffic patterns
column3: Programmed with scripts. Monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and alerts admin; may take *some* action to block

column1: DMARC Meaning >  Domain based Message *what*?
column3: DMARC verifies email senders by building on DNS; DKIM and SPF. Has a policy mechanism for senders to specify how authentication failures should be treated.

column1: Set of rules that control which users or systems can access network resources
column3: ACLs can be configured on various network devices like routers; switches; and firewalls to regulate traffic

column1: Fancy term for a mail client
column3: Usually uses port 587 to submit mail to an SMTP server. Can also refer to that server in broader definitions.

column1: Fancy term for an SMTP server
column3: uses DNS to find MX record and usually uses port 25 to send to remote mail server.

column1: SDN Meaning in cloud computing
column3: Centralized network control where software defines traffic flow using APIs; separates control from hardware for flexibility and automation

column1: Another name for SMB protocol
column3: SMB/CIFS Implement WIndows-compatible file and printer sharing services on a local network

column1: What does PCI mean?
column3: An industry-standard; high-speed bus found in nearly all desktop computers.

column1: Charging a fully charged battery at a rate equal to its self-discharge rate
column3: Repeated trickle charging can reduce battery life; use a power management plan/driver

column1: Store Li-ion batteries below what % charge/ºC
column3: Li-ion batteries are sensitive to heat

column1: First thing to test in a no power scenario
column3: Check that other equipment in the area is working; Try known-good equipment in outlet & cable plugged/known-good power cable

column1: Next steps in no power if outlet & cable confirmed
column3: May need higher wattage PSU or one of the devices is faulty. Can also test PSU with multimeter or power supply tester**.

column1: The per-use billing for resources consumed by the cloud
column3: based on the type of resource such as storage; processing; bandwidth; or active users. should be accessible to the customer via a reporting dashboard.

column1: Citrix/Microsoft's Application Virtualization solutions
column3: Client accesses application hosted on a server or streams it from the server.

column1: CSP Meaning?
column3: A public (or multitenant) model is offered over the internet by CSP's to cloud consumers; often referred to as tenants. (subscriptions or pay-as-you-go)

column1: Improves virtual *memory* performance in VM's Top/Intel/AMD
column3: Second Level Address Translation / Extended Page Table (Intel) / Rapid Virtualization Indexing (AMD)

column1: SAN Meaning
column3: is a network of storage devices that can be accessed by multiple servers or computers; providing a shared pool of storage space.

column1: Malware moves from one VM to another and attempts to interact with the hypervisor
column3: Breaking isolation between virtual machines is known as virtual machine escape

column1: Too many virtual machines are created without proper management
column3: Virtual machine sprawl increases security and maintenance risks

column1: VM's installed without proper authorization
column3: System management software can detect rogue VM's; deployment procedures should be tightly drafted and monitored

column1: a type of malicious code embedded in software that remains dormant until specific conditions are met
column3: You really don't want to be deploying VM images with these hiding in them

column1: Uses ground-basesd long-range fixed access wireless technology to provide internet access
column3: The WISP installs and maintains a directional antenna to bridge customers network and service provider

column1: Uses a VSAT antenna connected via coax to a DVB-S modem
column3: Satellite does not move relative to the Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT) dish. DVB-S is Digital Video Broadcast Satellite. Low speed/High Latency (>600ms)

column1: Requires an antenna with a motor and "phased array" technology
column3: LEO supports better bandwidth (around 70-100 Mbps) and lower latency (100-200 ms RTT)

column1: 3G format that allows a removable SIM card in unlocked handsets
column3: GSM: 3G works in 850/1900 MHz freq bands (mostly Americas) and 900/1800 in rest of world.

column1: 3G format where handset directly managed by provider with no removable SIM card
column3: CDMA: Area served by each base in 3G refered to as a "cell". Cells have effective range up to 5 miles(8km)

column1: Minimal cellular service levels with speeds 50-400 Kbps (3 with spaces)
column3: Not even 3G - 2G era tech or in-between

column1: Approximate speed of regular 3G UMTS/CDMA networks (Mbps)
column3: Universal Mobile Telecommunications Service (UMTS) on GSM / Evolution-Data Optimized (EV-DO) on CDMA

column1: Maximum speed of HSPA+ cellular (Mbps)
column3: High Speed Packet Access (HSPA) provides improved data on GSM networks

column1: DiplayPort MST meaning and versions (#/#) for daisy chaining
column3: You can connect up to four monitors to a desktop or three to a laptop. Can handle two 4K monitors at 60Hz or one 8K monitor at 30Hz.

column1: Thunderbolt can daisy chain up to how many devices?
column3: including external GPUs; storage drives; docking stations; and monitors

column1: Thunderbolt 4 supports up to #/# of monitors: 4K at 60Hz/8K at 60Hz
column3: Max speed 40Gbps. A strong choice for users who need ultra-high-definition visuals.

column1: DisplayPort speeds per lane (Original/Current version 2.0 - Gbps)
column3: Up to 4 bonded lanes = max speed of 80Gbps

column1: Next step in wired conn troubleshooting if cables good and connected?
column3: This will verify the integrity of the network interface port by checking that it can receive a signal generated by itself.

column1: Next step if you confirm patch cable and interface ports are good?
column3: Could also be a termination or external interference problem.

column1: Final steps in troubleshooting wired connectivity
column3: speed/duplex settings should usually be set to autonegotiate. You can also try updating driver.

column1: If the temperature is too high the CPU and other components are likely to do what
column3: Check temperature sensors and fan speeds. Maybe computer needs cleaning or cooling systems need to be replaced or upgraded.

column1: First thing to check in network speed troubleshooting (after narrowing down what they doing) 1/2
column3: Should be 'autonegotiate'; then measure transfer rate independent of specific apps or network services.

column1: What can cause interference in network besides external factors
column3: Check the ends of cables for excessive untwisting of the wire pairs or improper termination. Can also use network tap to look for damaged frames.

column1: Record used to identify an email server for the domain so that other servers can send messages to it
column3: MX: a DNS record that routes emails to specified mail servers.

column1: Uses a TXT record published via DNS to identify the hosts authorized to send email from that domain.
column3: With an SPF record in place; ISPs can verify that a mail server is authorized to send email for a specific domain.

column1: Uses cryptography to validate the source server for a given email message.
column3: To configure DKIM; the organization uploads a public encryption key as a TXT record.

column1: Handles email auth failures with policy in DNS (acronym)
column3: Builds on SPF and DKIM by adding control over failed authentication (e.g. reject/quarantine/monitor)

column1: What kind of lighting do most smartphone and tablet screens use?
column3: LEDs arranged at top or bottom of the screen; a diffuser makes the light evenly bright across whole screen

column1: Two main drawbacks of OLED displays? ?/?
column3: technically called active-matrix OLED (AMOLED) these are NOT considered LCD or TFT displays.

column1: What protocol allows secure upload/download of files to external users?
column3: Uses SSL/TLS to encrypt file transfers over FTP; ideal for sharing with outside collaborators

column1: What Windows-native protocol allows file and printer sharing internally?
column3: Can be encrypted in newer versions like SMBv3 but not typically exposed to external users

column1: What legacy protocol supports name resolution and older Windows file sharing?
column3: Very outdated and insecure; uses ports 137–139 and shouldn't be used externally

column1: What does the "T" in 1000BASE-T stand for?
column3: Commonly copper cables like Cat5e/Cat6 used for Gigabit Ethernet

column1: FttC VDSL speeds asymmetric down/up symmetric down/up (in Mbps)
column3: rated for 300m (1000 feet); Very High-Speed DSL 2 (VDSL2) gets 100 Mbps over 100m (300 feet)

column1: What do we call 192.168.10.0 on /24 subnet?
column3: First IP address in the subnet

column1: What do we call 192.168.10.255 in a /24 subnet?
column3: Last IP used to reach all devices in the subnet

column1: How many usable hosts are in a /24 subnet?
column3: 256 total minus 2 (network + broadcast)

column1: How many usable hosts are in a /16 subnet?
column3: 65536 total minus 2 (network + broadcast)

column1: Core of the internet is high b/w fiber connecting what?
column3: These trunk links and IXP's are mostly created by telecommunications companies and academic institutions.

column1: supports long distances over precise directional antennas; requires line-of-sight
column3: Point-to-point; uses ground-based high-gain microwave antennas that must be precisely aligned with one another. (up to 30 Miles)

column1: Range of precisely aligned high-gain directional antenna transmission (aprox)
column3: as long as they are unobstructed by physical objects. The antennas themselves are typically affixed to the top of tall buildings or mounted on tall poles.

column1: Wi-Fi signal strength is measured in
column3: dBm: signal strength represented as a ratio of measure to 1 mW; 1 mW is 0 dBm and negatives are fractions of a mW.

column1: The amount that a signal is boosted by directionality/measured in?
column3: focusing the signal in a single direction rather than spreading it over a wide area.

column1: The sum of transmit power; antenna cable/connector loss and antenna gain
column3: EIRP is the sum of transmit power and gain; expressed in dBm.

column1: What is the maximum downtime per year with five nines of availability?
column3: Aim for <5.256 minutes/year; for fewer nines move decimal right (more downtime); for more nines move it left (less downtime)

column1: ACPI Meaning?
column3: a power management standard that defines power states such as "sleep" and "hibernate."

column1: POST memory error beeps?
column3: Problem with system memory or memory controller

column1: POST beeps for Power supply fault or motherboard problem?
column3: tip for black screen no beeps: 1) ask what has changed; 2) check cable and connections; 3) check faulty interface and devices

column1: POST beeps for Motherboard problem?
column3: tip for black screen no beeps: 4) check the PSU; 5) check for faulty CPU or system firmware (maybe update it)

column1: POST beeps for Video adapter problem?
column3: extra tip: keyboard issue or key stuck is 3 long beeps

column1: Graphics cards use what kind of memory?
column3: Graphics DDR: 3-D cards need a substantial amount of memory for processing and texture effects.

column1: Network layer protocol used for error reporting & diagnostics (ping/tracert too)
column3: ICMP: Mainly used to determine whether or not data is reaching intended destination in a timely manner.

column1: 3D printing: a flat glass plate onto which the material is extruded. Usually heated to prevent warping
column3: The bed must be leveled for each print job—this is usually automated; but cheaper printer models require manual calibration.

column1: 3D printing: a sheet placed onto the base plate to hold the object. Allows removal after completion
column3: The bed surface material may need to be matched to the filament material for best results.

column1: Stereolithography (SLA) 3D printing uses what to print?
column3: uses liquid plastic resin or photopolymer to create objects which are cured using an ultraviolet laser.

column1: 3D printing method that fuses layers together using a pulse laser
column3: SLS: The object is created from a powder and lowered into a tank as each layer is added. The powder can be plastic or metal.

column1: Two most popular plastics for fillament in 3D printing? ?/?
column3: 'Polylactic Acid' (PLA) and 'Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene' (ABS). Most printers can use a range of filament types; but it is best to check compatibility.

column1: Bluetooth 4 introduced this non backwards compatible standard (acronym)
column3: Bluetooth Low Energy: designed for small battery-powered devices that transmit small amounts of data infrequently. ~1Mbps

column1: Bluetooth aprox range in feet (earliest/newest)
column3: early max was 10m (30 feet); newer can go over 100 ft though signal strength will be weak. v5 legit says over 240 METERS.

column1: Bluetooth max theoretical speed (v2/v3 in Mbps)
column3: EDR (Enhanced Data Rate) gives 3 Mbps in v2.0; v3.0 uses Wi-Fi for 24 Mbps bursts; v5.0 tops out at 2 Mbps in Low Energy mode.

column1: CHADDR Meaning
column3: stores the MAC address in "Client MAC address" field on DCHP protocol

column1: PCIe wattage supplied to dedicated graphics card slot/other cards
column3: An extra 75W power can be supplied via a PCIe power connector

column1: PSTN Meaning
column3: Core is fiber optic; at the edge is still often legacy two pair copper cabling (POTS: Plain Old Telephone System)

column1: APIPA Meaning
column3: 169.254.x.x -> "Local Link Only" enables communication within local network

column1: HDMI 2.0 and 2.1 Premium High Speed / Ultra High Speed (Gbps)
column3: High-Definition Multimedia Interface: supports both video and audio; plus remote control and digital content protection (HDCP)

column1: What old Thunderbolt 1 and 2 ports are the same shape as?
column3: TB1/2 ports can carry Mini DP signals but Mini DP ports do not support Thunderbolt signals.

column1: An adaptation of an old interface still used for enterprise-class storage devices
column3: Faster and more reliable than SATA; supports dual-porting and full-duplex for redundancy and performance in servers.

column1: Another name for the x86-32 instruction set
column3: Intel Architecture 32

column1: IOPS Meaning (storage)
column3: A measure of a storage device's read/write speed. It refers to the number of input/output (I/O) operations the device can complete in a second.

column1: Allows devices to discover each other and automatically configure port forwarding on routers
column3: Convenient for home use; but considered insecure for enterprise networks.

column1: IPv6 link-local address prefix?
column3: Used for communication within a local network segment; required for autoconfiguration and mDNS.

column1: Global IPv6 Starts with a # or #? (#/#)
column3: ISP might get 2001:0db8:abcd::/48; designate 2001:0db8:abcd:6e00::/56 city or region; and office might be 2001:0db8:abcd:6e11::/64 Lan!

column1: IPv6 auto-addressing using RA (no DHCP needed)
column3: Stateless Address Autoconfiguration: Uses Router Advertisements from ND to auto-configure global & link-local addresses without DHCP.

column1: IPv6 function to discover routers and local hosts
column3: ND: Handles router/prefix discovery; duplicate address detection; and neighbor reachability.

column1: RFID Range Passive/Active
column3: passive device that only responds when scanned at close range (up to about 25 m) or a powered; active device with a range of 100 m.

column1: Paper types impact printer use
column3: Ensure that the lever is in the correct position for friction feed or tractor feed as appropriate for the media being used.

column1: Moving roller in an impact printer
column3: Plain paper is held firmly against the platen; The holes on tractor-fed paper are secured over studded rollers at each end of the platen.

column1: IP meaning (device protection)
column3: A case or device will have two numbers; such as IP67. The first (6) is a rating for repelling solids and the second (7) is for repelling liquids.

column1: IP code for dust proof/immersion protection beyond 1m
column3: If dust protection is unrated; the IP value will be IPX7 or IPX8. IP57 is dust protected and immersion protection UP to 1m.

column1: Legacy Serial Port is also known as what/commonly uses what connector?
column3: RS-232 specifies a 25-pin hardware interface; but in practice; PC manufacturers used the cheaper 9-pin D-subminiature (DB-9) female port

column1: TCP connection sequence packet identifiers (???/???)
column3: Connection handshake sequence of SYN; SYN/ACK; and ACK packets. Assigns each packet a sequence number so that it can be tracked.

column1: TCP receiver code to force retransmission of a missing or damaged packet?
column3: Also the termination of a session uses the FIN code. The client requesting connection ususally generates a random port number for responses.

column1: If one of the underlying devices in RAID array fails volume will be listed as
column3: Data on the volume will still be accessible and it should continue to function as a boot device if so configured. (Not RAID 0 tho)

column1: K on Intel Processors means?
column3: High performance/Unlocked to be more specific

column1: A layer 2 protocol used to map MAC addresses to IP addresses
column3: The ARP packet contains a simple question: What is the MAC address corresponding to IP address

column1: Server-class motherboards include support for extra ?/?
column3: There are dedicated CPU ranges for servers; such as Intel’s Xeon and AMD’s Epyc brands.

column1: AMD Socket for Threadripper CPUs
column3: Used for high-end desktop and workstation CPUs with up to 64 cores and massive PCIe lanes

column1: Laser printing issue - Black stripes or whole page black (stage?)
column3: Primary Charge Roller (PCR) is dirty or damaged or High Voltage Power Supply (HVPS) is fucked.

column1: Laser printing issue - Blank pages ?/?/?
column3: Driver problem; toner installed without removing packing seals; or possible transfer roller damaged (image not transfering)

column1: Laser printing issue - Vertical or horizontal lines appear in same place (Repetitive Defects) ?/?
column3: Dirty feed rollers (may be in toner or fuser too) or damaged/dirty photosensitive drum.

column1: Laser printing issue - Double/Echo images (stage?)
column3: drum has not been fully cleaned; repeat images on same page or next pages; printing a bunch may fix or replace drum/toner.

column1: Laser printing issue - Cast or Shadow like effect (issue?)
column3: Transfer belt or one/all of the cartridges may be misaligned. Reseat and run calibration utility.

column1: Laser printing issue - Color missing (solutions ?/?)
column3: replace the cartridge or clean the contacts between printer and cartridge.

column1: NFC Range(inches)/Max Speed(Kbps)
column3: 2in = 6cm; NFC is mostly used for contactless payment readers; security ID tags; and shop shelf-edge labels for stock control.

column1: One Meter equals how many Feet?
column3: 1 Foot = 0.3048 Meters. For an approximate result; divide the length (Feet) by 3.281

column1: One Inch equal how many Centimeters?
column3: 1 Centimeter = 0.3937 Inches. Divide the length (Centimeters) by 2.54

column1: Unlicensed frequency for LRFW besides 2.4 and 5 Ghz
column3: Anyone can use these frequencies; meaning that interference is a risk.

column1: Works out a device's location by triangulating its proximity to other radio sources
column3: derive a device's location when indoors by triangulating its proximity to radio sources such as Bluetooth beacons or Wi-Fi access points.

column1: SNR Meaning in wireless
column3: Noise is also measured in dBm; but here values closer to zero are less welcome; as they represent higher noise levels.

column1: 4G & 5G Standards that removed the CDMA/GSM distinction ?/?
column3: LTE-Advanced (on 4G/4G+) has a maximum downlink of 300 Mb/s in theory; real world is more like 20–90 Mb/s

column1: WPS meaning
column3: Enables simplified connection to a (usually home) Wi-Fi; most often using push button.

column1: Real world speeds of 5G (Mbps)
column3: They hoped for 1 Gb/s rate but that didn't play out.

column1: principal means of secure access to UNIX and Linux servers and to most types of network appliances
Which protocol is used for secure file transfer over SSH?
column3: Runs over port 22 and is built into the SSH protocol not to be confused with FTPS which uses FTP over TLS on ports 989 and 990

column1: Port 989/990/protocol
column3: Implicit FTPS — secure from the moment you connect uses these ports - Explicit FTPS uses control 21 and a random port for data.

column1: DDR3/4/5 max size in GB ?/?/?
column3: According to the course anyways -> shit is always improving.

column1: allows a Windows client to access a Linux host as though it were a Windows file or print server
column3: provides support for SMB in UNIX- or Linux-based machines and network attached storage (NAS) appliances

column1: database of information maintained by an SNMP agent
column3: MIB: holds statistics relating to the activity of the device. An example of such a statistic is the number of frames per second handled by a switch.

column1: Syslog severity level code
column3: Priority value: Facility and Severity of the message. Facility represents the part of the system sending the message; Severity marks its importance.

column1: CPU Power 8 Pin vs/4 Pin names
column3: Power connectors always have half square and halve rounded connectors

column1: Input VAC values in North America vs Europe (low-line)/(high-line)
column3: Most PSUs are dual voltage and are auto-switching; some have a manual switch; *Some are fixed voltage!*

column1: ATX Meaning in power supplies/motherboards
column3: Most systems are now based on the ATX12V version 2 specification. This defines a 24-pin (2x12) P1 form factor.

column1: Attached to each device in closed loop water cooling to remove heat by convection
column3: These are attached in a similar way to heat sink/fan assemblies and then connected to the water loop.

column1: PCI Max Transfer Speed (MBps)
column3: That is 32 bits divided by 8 to get 4 bytes; then multiplied by the clock rate of 33.3Mhz

column1: Full-size ATX board size (in)
column3: (305 mm x 244 mm). An ATX board can contain up to seven expansion slots.

column1: Micro-ATX (mATX) board size (in)
column3: (244 mm x 244 mm) square board. mATX boards can have a maximum of four expansion slots.

column1: Mini-ITX board size (in)
column3: (170 mm x 170 mm) square board. These are designed for small cases; but do note that most mini-ITX boards can be mounted in ATX cases.

column1: USB 3 headers on motherboard use (pinxpin)
column3: can be cabled to two ports.

column1: 3 or 4 pin Molex KK connectors are for?
column3: 4-pin fan connectors support pulse width modulation (PWM) signal carried by the blue wire. 3-pin fans are controlled by varying the voltage.

column1: What Cat Cable specification has two speed specs #/long/short
column3: [1 Gbps at @ 100 m (328 ft)] and [10 Gbps @ 55 m (180 ft)]

column1: Monitor communications passing over the switch using mirror port
column3: The sensor is attached to a specially configured port on a network switch. The mirror port receives copies of frames addressed to nominated access ports.

column1: Cable that uses treated PVC or fluorinated ethylene polymer (FEP) jackets
column3: CMP: Communications Multipurpose Plenum (General-purpose cables are marked as CMG or MMG for PVC jackets; and CM or MP for plenum-rated cables.)

column1: What laser printer component causes ghost images if it fails to remove leftover toner?
column3: Residual toner from previous print cycle causes faint duplicates

column1: What does the static eliminator strip or corona wire do in a laser printer?
column3: Prevents paper from sticking or attracting extra toner after transfer

column1: Which inkjet technology uses heat to form a bubble that ejects ink?
column3: A tiny heater boils ink to form a bubble that pushes droplets out. HP; Canon; Brother

column1: Which inkjet technology uses vibration from a crystal to eject ink?
column3: A voltage flexes a piezo crystal to force ink out without heat. Epson

column1: IDE Meaning
column3: Also known as PATA (Parallel Advanced Technology Attachment).  Pin 1 indicated by a red stripe on the side of cable.

column1: HBA Meaning (Re: SCSI)
column3: One SCSI host bus adapter (HBA) can control multiple devices attached by internal ribbon cables or external SCSI cables.

column1: An advanced type of cable tester
column3: Can report detailed information about cable performance and interference.

column1: EIDE cable connector colors: Device 0/Device 1/Motherboard
column3: Enhanced integrated drive electronics. Pin 1 has red stripe on that side.

column1: Inkjet carriage system uses these 3 to move print head ?/?/?
column3: Plus a guide shaft to keep the print head stable; and sensors to detect the position of the print head.

column1: Prevents more than one sheet entering an inkjet printer
column3: A load roller turns against the paper stack to move the top sheet while a separation roller prevents more than one sheet entering.

column1: The power supply standard that changed from 20 to 24 pin main MB connector
column3: This can also refer to the 4 pin square CPU connector; it's whatever.

column1: Generic/Intel/AMD alternate names for EM64T
column3: Extends the x86 instruction set for 64-bit operation.

column1: How is DDR5 different from DDR4 in terms of channel layout?
column3: DDR5 still transfers 64 bits per cycle total but uses two 32-bit channels to reduce latency and improve multi-core performance

column1: HSM Meaning
column3: A secure USB key or thumb drive used to store cryptographic material; user must authenticate before they can access the keys stored on the module.

column1: Which security feature stores and compares hashes of boot components?
column3: This is part of TPM’s measured boot process to detect tampering

column1: What is a network drop?
column3: It’s where a device connects to the network using structured cabling and is often tested during hardware troubleshooting

column1: RMA Meaning?
column3: If a part or system is under warranty; you can return the broken part for a replacement with RMA ticket from vendor.

column1: A passive network TAP uses ?/?
column3: No logic decisions are made; so the monitor port receives every frame—corrupt or malformed or not—and the copying is unaffected by load.

column1: An active network TAP uses?
column3: Gigabit signaling over copper wire is too complex for a passive tap to monitor; and some types of fiber links may be adversely affected by optical splitting.
